conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on blocks A and B.
Block A is on the ground; Block B is in contact with A.
Define mass of block A as m_A and mass of block B as m_B.
Identify forces on Block A: vertical forces include weight of A, normal force from ground, frictional force from B; horizontal force is frictional force from ground.
Identify forces on Block B: vertical forces include weight of B, normal force from A; horizontal forces include applied force and frictional force from A.
Block A is about to slip, so frictional force from ground is at maximum: f_A = μ_2 N_A = m_A g.
Block B is about to slide down, so frictional force from A is at maximum: f_AB = μ_1 N_BA = m_B g.
Since f_AB = f_BA, we have μ_1 N_BA = m_B g.
Normal force N_BA is equal to the weight of B: N_BA = m_B g.
Substitute N_BA into frictional force equation: μ_1 m_B g = m_B g.
Normal force from ground N_A is the sum of weights of A and B: N_A = m_A g + m_B g.
Frictional force from ground is μ_2 N_A = μ_2 (m_A g + m_B g).
Equate frictional forces: μ_2 (m_A g + m_B g) = m_A g.
Solve for mass ratio: μ_2 (m_A + m_B) = m_A.
Rearrange to find m_A/m_B: m_A (1 - μ_2) = μ_2 m_B.
Final mass ratio of A to B is μ_2/(1 - μ_2).
